title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the forested hillside in Northern Manhattan mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the only area in New York City with coyotes.

options.label: B
options.text: It has the highest population of white-footed mice.

options.label: C
options.text: It is one of the last areas with clean spring water seeping out of the ground.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the largest park in New York City.

multiple-choice.question: What has happened to the population of northern dusky salamanders in New York City over the past 60 years?

options.label: A
options.text: They have become more widespread throughout the city.

options.label: C
options.text: They are now only found on a single hillside and a few places in Staten Island.

multiple-choice.question: How can researchers tell which side of the bridge a salamander came from?

options.label: C
options.text: By taking a few segments of DNA from the salamander.

multiple-choice.question: What is a notable characteristic of coyotes that are moving into New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: They are very timid and avoid human interaction.

options.label: B
options.text: They are very flexible and intelligent animals.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only found in the Bronx.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only active at night.

multiple-choice.question: Why are researchers studying the white-footed mouse in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is an invasive species.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a native species that can be used as a model to understand how species adapt to urban environments.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the most common mouse species in the city.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the largest mouse species in the city.

multiple-choice.question: What has happened to the population of white-footed mice in New York City over the past 400 years?

options.label: A
options.text: They have become more widespread throughout the city.

options.label: C
options.text: They are now only found in small islands of forest scattered around the city.

multiple-choice.question: How can researchers determine which park a white-footed mouse came from?

options.label: C
options.text: By using 18 short segments of DNA.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from city mice and comparing them to genes from country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how mice adapt to different climates.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how mice adapt to urban environments.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how mice interact with each other.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how mice respond to predators.

multiple-choice.question: What is a Manhattan plot, and what does it show?

options.label: A
options.text: A graph that shows the population size of mice in different parks.

options.label: B
options.text: A graph that shows the genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: C
options.text: A graph that shows the distribution of mice in different neighborhoods.

options.label: D
options.text: A graph that shows the number of genes in a mouse genome.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the genes that have been found to be different between city and country mice, and what do they encode for?

options.label: A
options.text: Genes that encode for fur color and body size.

options.label: B
options.text: Genes that encode for immune response to disease, metabolism, and heavy-metal tolerance.

options.label: C
options.text: Genes that encode for behavior and social interaction.

options.label: D
options.text: Genes that encode for diet and nutrition.

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What was Malcolm McLean's occupation during the Great Depression of the 1930s?
What was the primary source of Malcolm McLean's frustration while waiting at the docks in Hoboken, New Jersey?

options.label: B
options.text: The inefficiency of the loading and unloading process

options.label: C
options.text: The noise level on the docks

options.label: D
options.text: The long drive from North Carolina

multiple-choice.question: What was the traditional method of shipping general non-bulk cargo called?
How long did it typically take to haul and distribute break bulk shipments in the hold, plus retrieve and distribute at the other end?
What concept did Malcolm McLean envision to revolutionize the shipping industry?
How old was Malcolm McLean when he first had the idea of containerization?
Who helped Malcolm McLean finance his containerization project?

options.label: A
options.text: A vice president at Citibank in New York

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship?
Where did the Ideal X sail from on its maiden voyage?

options.label: A
options.text: Shed 154 at Marsh Street, Port Newark

multiple-choice.question: What is credited as the primary reason for the thriving global marketplace and the ability to move cargo at minimal cost?

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary goal in the given situation?

options.label: B
options.text: To obtain financial aid for education

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions putting their hands on top of their head and staying calm. What is the purpose of this action?

options.label: D
options.text: To signal the start of a game

multiple-choice.question: The speaker references several famous musicians, including Tupac and Biggie Smalls. What is the purpose of these references?

options.label: B
options.text: To express their emotions and frustration

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions their ancestors and the struggles they faced. What is the purpose of this reference?

options.label: B
options.text: To express gratitude for their ancestors' sacrifices

options.label: C
options.text: To highlight the ongoing struggle for equality and access to education

options.label: D
options.text: To shift the focus away from the current situation

options.label: A
options.text: They believe it is fair and accessible

options.label: B
options.text: They think it is a game and not to be taken seriously

options.label: C
options.text: They feel it is a system designed to hold people back and create debt

options.label: D
options.text: They are neutral and have no opinion

options.label: A
options.text: To provide historical context and highlight ongoing systemic issues

options.label: B
options.text: To showcase their knowledge of history

options.label: C
options.text: To distract from the current situation

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's tone throughout the transcript?
The speaker mentions their cousins in Haiti and their best friend Raymond. What is the purpose of these references?

options.label: B
options.text: To express their emotions and personal connections

options.label: C
options.text: To highlight the struggles faced by others

options.label: D
options.text: To shift the focus away from the current situation

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's ultimate goal, as stated in the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: To get their education and learn

multiple-choice.question: The speaker repeats the phrase "put the money in the bag" throughout the transcript. What is the purpose of this repetition?

options.label: A
options.text: To intimidate others and create a sense of urgency

options.label: B
options.text: To emphasize their primary goal and create a sense of desperation

options.label: C
options.text: To distract from the current situation

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sense of humor and lightheartedness

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: In the transcript, what phrase does Dorothy say from "The Wizard of Oz"?

options.label: A
options.text: No coordinates exist like one's domicile

options.label: D
options.text: I want to go to the Emerald City

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why do $10 words often fail?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive to use

options.label: B
options.text: They are not understood by the audience

options.label: C
options.text: They are too short to convey meaning

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used by novelists

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of the transcript regarding word choice?

options.label: B
options.text: Using a thesaurus is essential for good writing

options.label: C
options.text: Knowing your audience is crucial for effective word choice

options.label: D
options.text: All writing should be at a fourth-grade reading level

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on using complex vocabulary in writing?

options.label: C
options.text: It's worthless if not understood by the audience

options.label: D
options.text: It's the key to good writing

options.label: A
options.text: Use as many complex words as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Write at a fourth-grade reading level

options.label: C
options.text: Get to the point and be brief

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the right words to use

options.label: B
options.text: Competing against a whole world of distractions

options.label: C
options.text: Writing at a fourth-grade reading level

multiple-choice.question: What does the author mean by "brevity is its bread and butter"?

options.label: A
options.text: That using complex words is essential

options.label: B
options.text: That being concise is essential for effective communication

options.label: C
options.text: That writing should be as long as possible

options.label: D
options.text: That using a thesaurus is crucial

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on the use of vivid descriptors in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They should only be used by novelists

options.label: B
options.text: They are essential for all types of writing

options.label: C
options.text: They are only necessary for certain types of writing

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the consequence of using words that are not understood by the audience?
What is the author's suggestion for those who want to use complex words?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them as much as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Save your money and buy a Scrabble board

options.label: C

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "symbiosis" refer to in the context of life sciences?

options.label: A
options.text: A competition between two different species

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species

options.label: C
options.text: A predator-prey relationship between two species

options.label: D
options.text: A parasitic relationship between two species

multiple-choice.question: Which bird species is involved in a symbiotic relationship with the whitebark pine tree?
Where do whitebark pine trees typically grow?

options.label: B
options.text: In the mountains of Wyoming, Montana, and other western states

options.label: C
options.text: In the tropical rainforests of South America

options.label: D
options.text: In the deserts of North Africa

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of squirrels in the ecosystem of the whitebark pine tree?

options.label: B
options.text: They disperse the seeds by burying them in piles

options.label: C
options.text: They protect the trees from predators

options.label: D
options.text: They compete with the Clark's nutcracker for seeds

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way Clark's nutcrackers store seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They store them in their nests

options.label: B
options.text: They store them in a pouch in their throat

options.label: C
options.text: They store them in underground burrows

options.label: D
options.text: They store them in tree cavities

multiple-choice.question: How many seeds can a Clark's nutcracker store in its throat pouch?
How do Clark's nutcrackers remember the location of their cached seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: They use landmarks on the landscape to triangulate to caches

options.label: C
options.text: They use a mental map of the forest

options.label: D
options.text: They use a combination of all the above

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the seeds that Clark's nutcrackers do not retrieve?

options.label: A
options.text: They are eaten by other animals

options.label: D
options.text: They are dispersed by the wind

multiple-choice.question: How have whitebark pine trees evolved to suit the Clark's nutcracker?

options.label: A
options.text: Their branches have become shorter and more dense

options.label: B
options.text: Their cones have become smaller and less accessible

options.label: C
options.text: Their branches sweep upwards with the cones at the very ends

options.label: D
options.text: Their trunks have become thicker and more robust

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of the symbiotic relationship between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine tree?

options.label: A
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker gets food, and the whitebark pine tree gets protection

options.label: B
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker gets shelter, and the whitebark pine tree gets nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker gets seeds, and the whitebark pine tree gets its seeds dispersed

options.label: D
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine tree both benefit from each other's presence

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

multiple-choice.question: How many Earths could fit inside the sun?
Approximately how many stars are in the Milky Way galaxy?
If each star was the size of a grain of sand, how large of an area would the Milky Way's stars cover?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 feet by 10 feet, one foot deep

options.label: B
options.text: 30 feet by 30 feet, three feet deep

multiple-choice.question: How many galaxies are detectable by our telescopes?
What is the predicted number of universes in the multiverse according to the leading version of string theory?
What is the concept of the multiverse in physics?

options.label: A
options.text: A single universe with multiple dimensions

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple universes with different properties and laws

options.label: C
options.text: A universe with infinite space-time continuum

options.label: D
options.text: A universe with only one set of physical laws

options.label: B
options.text: Universes with different properties and dimensions

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple universes spawned every moment, some similar to our own

options.label: D
options.text: A single universe with multiple parallel dimensions

multiple-choice.question: What is the range of possible answers to the question of how many universes there are?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a clear consensus on a single answer

options.label: B
options.text: There are two competing theories with equal support

options.label: C
options.text: There is no agreement, with a wide range of possible answers

options.label: D
options.text: The question is no longer relevant in modern physics

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with solving the Challenger disaster and winning the Nobel Prize in Physics for his Feynman diagrams?
What phenomenon did Richard Feynman's father describe as "inertia" when explaining why a ball moved to the back of a wagon?

options.label: C
options.text: The tendency of an object to maintain its state of motion

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with being the first person to accurately measure the circumference of the Earth?
How did Eratosthenes determine the circumference of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: By measuring the distance between two points on the Earth's surface and using the angle of the sun's shadow

options.label: B
options.text: By using a complex mathematical formula

options.label: C
options.text: By observing the Earth's shadow on the moon

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with proving that the Earth is spherical using the observation of the Earth's shadow on the moon?
What was Armand Fizeau's specialty as an experimental physicist?

options.label: C
options.text: Refining and confirming other people's results

multiple-choice.question: Who attempted to measure the speed of light using a lamp-based experiment?
How did Armand Fizeau measure the speed of light?

options.label: B
options.text: Using a toothed wheel to send discrete pulses of light

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the concept that describes the idea that scientific discoveries can be made by anyone using their eyes, ears, and minds?
